posts.title: A Manhattanhenge Reading List
posts.text: Manhattanhenge is coming, and we’ve made a reading list to celebrate!

posts.title: Summer Reading 2019: A Women's Literary World Cup
posts.text: Are you watching the Women’s World Cup? To keep up the international mood between matches, we have reading suggestions featuring women authors from the 24 countries competing in the 2019 Women’s World Cup. Some teams may have been eliminated, but our Literary World Cup teams are still going strong!

posts.title: Tasty Patron Picks and Engrossing Winter Reads from Open Book Hour
posts.text: Every month at our Open Book Hour, Mid-Manhattan readers meet to trade fiction and nonfiction book recommendations. Today, we’d like to share their picks from the past few months with you.

posts.title: What's Your Number? Celebrating Dewey Decimal System Day
posts.text: We don't usually have conversations in code at the Library, but we do love Dewey Decimal call numbers. Did you wake up this morning with some 641.3373? Spend any time doing 746.46 last weekend? Come check out our favorite numbers!

posts.title: Leave the Lights On! Scary Patron Picks from Open Book Hour
posts.text: What's your favorite type of scary story? Creepy true crime? Ghoulish ghost stories? See what NYPL patrons picked from the latest Open Book Hour.

posts.title: Summer Reading: 2018 Literary World Cup
posts.text: Not sure who to root for in the 2018 FIFA World Cup? How about selecting and celebrating your favorite international authors? It makes for some interesting head-to-head matchups.

posts.title: Picture This: Graphic Novel Patron Picks from Open Book Hour
posts.text: At the latest Open Book Hour at the Mid-Manhattan Library at 42nd Street, attendees shared their favorite graphic novels and comic books. Here's the list.

posts.title: Celebrating Our Roots: Patron Picks from Open Book Hour
posts.text: From the immigrant experience to the history of CBGB, our latest Open Book Hour revealed a diverse set of recommendations.

posts.title: From the Heart and Out of This World: Patron Picks from Open Book Hour
Politics, Robots, and Fictional Escapes: Patron Picks from Open Book Hour
posts.text: What are some NYPL patrons currently reading? Here's the latest list from patrons at the Mid-Manhattan Library at 42nd Street.

posts.title: Food, Family, Feuds: Patron Picks from Open Book Hour
posts.text: Delicious recipes, dysfunctional families, high stakes feuds... Check out these patron picks!

posts.title: Liberty and Happiness: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: Classic self-help books, engaging fiction, 18th-century American history, and Jane Austen were some of the topics we discussed at our last Open Book Night, when the theme was “liberty and happiness.”

posts.title: Planes, Trains, and Automobiles: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: Epic journeys by ship and by train, stories of survival in wartime, and elephants were some of the topics we discussed at last month’s Open Book Night. We asked readers to share a reading journey with us, including books about travel and transportation, favorite armchair adventures, or virtual voyages.

posts.title: May 2017 International Fiction Bestsellers
posts.text: This month we checked out fiction bestsellers in Belgium, Brazil, Finland, Peru, and Taiwan and found a mixture of novels by local authors, translations of international bestsellers, and some poetry.

posts.title: We Are New Yorkers: A Reading List for NYC Immigrant Heritage Week
posts.text: Here are some vivid representations of the New York immigrant experience in fiction, as well as a few memoirs and biographies of New Yorkers past and present, who arrived here from all over the world and made their mark on our city.

posts.title: March 2017 International Fiction Bestsellers
posts.text: Are you interested in what people around the world are reading? Travel the bestseller lists with us! This month we checked out bestsellers in Colombia, Egypt, Greece, Ireland, and Malaysia.

posts.title: Life in All Its Granite Hardness: A Selection of Irish Noir
posts.text: Bleak, dark, grimly realistic, morally and psychologically complex with a dash of gallows humor. Scandinavian Noir has some serious competition from its Irish cousin. Check out some Irish crime writers this St. Patrick’s Day weekend.

posts.title: Ain't Nothin' but a Book Love Thang: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: Our theme this month was “Ain’t Nothin’ but a Love Thang”, and we asked readers to share books they love, books about love, and books about things they love.

posts.title: 2016 International Fiction Bestsellers
posts.text: Which fiction titles topped the charts around the world last year? We looked at bestseller lists for 2016 from nine other countries.

posts.title: Food and Celebration: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: Last month when we gathered for Open Book Night, our theme was food and celebration. Oysters came up several times as well as some fictional meals that were far from celebratory. We heard about favorite cookbooks and food memoirs and a few titles readers really enjoyed that had little to do with food but fit the mood.

posts.title: Happy National Cookie (Lit) Day!
posts.text: We're celebrating National Cookie Day with a list of literary-related cookie recipes.

posts.title: November 2016 International Fiction Bestsellers
posts.text: This month, we took a close look at the bestseller lists in Canada, Dominican Republic, Israel, Portugal, and Turkey to see what fiction titles are popular with readers there.

posts.title: Shakespeare Around the Globe: Films and Books in the World Languages Collection
posts.text: Discover world cinema inspired by Shakespeare’s plays.

posts.title: September 2016 International Fiction Bestsellers: China, Nigeria, Poland, Spain, UAE
posts.text: Do you ever wonder what books are popular with readers in other countries? We do, so we’ve been taking a look at some bestseller lists from around the world to see what people are reading.

posts.title: Olympic Reading: 192 Authors from around the World
posts.text: As the 2016 Olympic Games draw to a close in Rio, don’t let that feeling of international fellowship and connection fade away.

posts.title: Summer in the City: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: At our last Open Book Night at Mid-Manhattan Library, we asked readers to share a quintessential summer in the city book, a book that evokes summer in New York or another city or a book that helps them survive summer in the city.

posts.title: July 2016 International Fiction Bestsellers: France, Mexico, Singapore, South Korea, and Sweden
posts.text: What are people reading around the world?

posts.title: The Natural World: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: Books about hiking, evolution, human nature, dogs and cats, city parks and gardens, and classic fiction were among the titles readers recommended at our Open Book Night last month when we suggested the topic “the natural world.”

posts.title: May 2016 International Fiction Bestsellers: Argentina, Brazil, Germany, Italy, Russia
posts.text: A satirical Swedish novel, a favorite Sicilian detective, and teen dystopian romance top the bestseller lists in Germany, Italy, and Brazil. Novels by native authors are popular in Argentina and Russia, and everyone loves Jojo Moyes!

posts.title: Learn English With Shakespeare: Free Websites and Books for English Language Learners
posts.text: Shakespeare’s language can be a challenge for fluent English speakers. If you’re an English language learner, you might think that Shakespeare is not for for you, but there are many different ways you can learn about his work, his life, and his language and improve your English skills.

posts.title: Women in Print: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: At our March Open Book Night readers recommended a wide variety of books by favorite women authors, from contemporary fiction to older favorites, even questioning the authorship of a great classic of Western literature.

posts.title: In With the New! A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: We had asked readers to tell us about a book that helped them explore or learn something new or to share a recently discovered book or author they loved.

posts.title: Recommended at Open Book Night: Patron Picks in "E"
posts.text: Not sure what to read next? Check out these book recommendations from fellow book lovers!

posts.title: Download Your Next Nonfiction Read: Author @ the Library in "E"
posts.text: Are you looking for a good nonfiction read to download? Every month the Mid-Manhattan Library presents a series of Author @ the Library lectures featuring recent nonfiction books on a wide range of subjects, and many of these titles are available  to borrow as e-books.

posts.title: Early 1970s Fiction: 45 Novels for 45 Years of Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Just in time for #tbt... award winners, best sellers and cultural touchstones from the early 1970s.

posts.title: Thankful for Books: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: At our last Open Book Night we asked our Mid-Manhattan readers to share a book or an author they were thankful for, or to tell us about a story or book they associated with Thanksgiving.

posts.title: New York: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: A wide variety of titles, including memoirs, essays, classic and contemporary fiction, history, and poetry connected to New York.

posts.title: September Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: If you'd like to understand why more wild animals are venturing into urban environments; to discover how the great impressionist Monet ate; to examine the Polaroid-Kodak patent war; to celebrate the music and poetry of Leonard Cohen; to learn how to beat fatigue; to  explore the economic consequences of climate change; to relive a harrowing but heroic moment in Armenian history; to argue against suicide; or learn how to cope with the narcissists in your life, please join us this month!

posts.title: August in the Reader's Den: A Walk in the Woods by Bill Bryson, Part 1
posts.text: Welcome back to the Reader’s Den!  This August we’re making a virtual escape from the hot and steamy New York summer with Bill Bryson’s classic travelogue, A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail, originally published in 1996.

posts.title: July Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Listen to scholars and other experts discuss their recent nonfiction books on a wide variety of subjects and ask them questions.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2015: A Women's Literary World Cup
posts.text: Are you watching the Women’s World Cup? The tournament began on June 6 with teams from 24 countries competing in cities around Canada, and the Round of 16 starts tomorrow. If you'd like to indulge in some reading between matches, we've got lots of suggestions for you. Whether or not you're  a soccer fan, you can cheer on your favorites in the Women's Literary World Cup. All readers are welcome!

posts.title: Humans and Nature: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: When we asked people to share books related to the theme of nature at our recent Open Book Night, we heard about titles related to both the natural world and to human nature, with an emphasis on humankind’s relationship to nature.

posts.title: May Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Dance in unexpected places... walking through literary New York... New York's incredible abandoned spaces... photographing  fashion's trendsetters... recipes in literature... unusual hiking destinations... coming of age in postwar America... the art and science of what we eat... southern Italy's most celebrated gardens... urban transformation in Chelsea... the influence of our infrastructure...

posts.title: New Beginnings: A Reading List from Open Book Night
posts.text: When we asked people to share books related to the theme of “new beginnings,” we got a really wide range of fiction and nonfiction book recommendations: spiritual, nutritional, philosophical, emotional, geographic, artistic, political, physical, and meteorological.

posts.title: March Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Drawing as a form of inquiry... groundbreaking graphic designers... The U.S.  a safe haven for Nazis... 1,000 years of visualizing the cosmos... a moment-by-moment account of Hurricane Sandy... the era of great American songwriting... the evolution of the painted nail...

posts.title: Presenting Open Book Night: Let's Talk About Love!
posts.text: We’re having our first book social at Mid-Manhattan and you’re invited! This month’s theme is love. We hope you’ll join us on Friday, February 13 to share a book you loved reading!

posts.title: We Know You Love to Talk About Books: Announcing the 2015 Reader's Den Online Book Discussion Schedule
posts.text: Are you making your New Year's Resolutions? Is one of them to read more or to connect more with other readers? We would love to see you in the Reader's Den, NYPL's online book discussion, in 2015!

posts.title: December Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: The lost tribe of Coney Island... building the Statue of Liberty... a culinary history of America in 100 bites... the sinking of refugee ship The Wilhelm Gustloff during World War II...  a close-up of the planet Mars... forgiving, remembering, and forgetting in personal and political contexts... a road trip through presidential libraries... curious New York activities... what online data can tell us about ourselves... reducing inequality in the 21st century... the history of New York's mass transit systems between 1940 and 1968... tales from a world traveler...

posts.title: October 2014 Reader's Den: "Going to the Dogs: The Story of a Moralist" by Erich Kästner, Part 1
posts.text: This month we’re taking a trip to Weimar Germany via Going to the Dogs: The Story of a Moralist by Erich Kästner, translated from the German by Cyrus Brooks. This novel, originally published in Germany in 1931 under the title Fabian, follows Jakob Fabian, a well educated but underemployed youngish man, as he moves through a decaying Berlin after the economic crash of 1929.

posts.title: October Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Are you interested in the history of free-market health care, classic DC comics, the story of an American bride in Kabul in 1961, or an American divorcee in 21st century Qatar, the pleasures of English gardens, rising Islamophobia, tales from 1940s post-war Germany, creating fashion portfolios, the life of early 20th century mover and shaker Mabel Dodge Luhan, GMO foods, new visions for urban life, or secular humanism?

posts.title: Travels as an Armchair Detective: Mysteries with a Sense of Place
posts.text: Summer's almost gone, and I haven’t been able to travel very far out of the city, so I’ve been doing the next best thing, vicariously experiencing far flung locales, and occasionally time periods, in the company of some of my favorite sleuths. Enjoy visiting these detectives' beats from your couch, in the park, on a beach, on the  subway, or anywhere else you like to read.

posts.title: August Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Philosophical inquiry at the movies… a looming retirement crisis… familiar New York landmarks seen from unexpected angles… the birth of NYC’s power system… the language hoax… the hidden history of the mob in NYC…   Tomorrow-Land, the 1964-1965 World’s Fair… the great Boston - New York subway race… the Kitty Genovese murder… the inventor of electric traction… the hospice movement… the makers of modern Manhattan…

posts.title: Summer Reading: A Literary World Cup
posts.text: Are you following the World Cup? Has that intense international feeling inspired you to look for some reading from around the globe? We’ve been inspired by the Los Angeles Public Library’s brilliant virtual #Literary World Cup to create our own Literary World Cup book display featuring authors from these competing countries. We hope you'll discover some new writers to enjoy!

posts.title: July Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
June Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: The rise and fall of the atomic era… achieving financial independence... legendary actor Stella Adler… millennia of Egyptomania… an exile’s return to Bosnia… Tammany Hall, a birthplace of progressive urban politics… the discovery of logic ... the art of quitting… tracking the New York art world… the history of the world’s most influential spice… blood libel in Tsarist Russia… imagining a socialist USA … bad English… the approaching death of money… dueling neurosurgeons...

posts.title: March Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: A new approach to health care reform ... 20 years of Harlem Street Portraits ... humanist architecture ... The Extreme Life of the Sea ... New York City's unbuilt subways ... mothers ... the power of storytelling ... a century of candy ... New York's lost amusement parks ... the public library ... 11 missing men of WWII ... great city planning.

posts.title: February Author @ the Library Programs at Mid-Manhattan
posts.text: Who was Miss Anne in 1920s Harlem? How did George Washington define the American presidency? What is keeping a majority of Americans from eating well? Can the world’s most endangered big cat be saved? How can we improve brain performance at any age? What fascinating stories does Murray Hill have to tell? Find out at Mid-Manhattan this month!
